data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom Version**: 1.12.0-beta7
**Electron Version**: 1.3.6
**System**: Mac OS X 10.12.1
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined

```
At /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/helpers.js:223

TypeError: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined
    at exports.keystrokeForKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/helpers.js:223:18)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.keystrokeForKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:430:14)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:318:24)
    at WindowEventHandler.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/window-event-handler.js:106:36)
    at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/window-event-handler.js:3:59)
```

### Commands

```
     -0:48 vim-mode:insert-below-with-newline (atom-text-editor.editor.vim-mode.normal-mode.is-focused)
 16x -0:40.4.0 core:backspace (atom-text-editor.editor.vim-mode.is-focused.insert-mode)
     -0:00.1.0 find-and-replace:show-replace (atom-text-editor.editor.vim-mode.is-focused.insert-mode)
```

### Config

```json
{
  "core": {
    "customFileTypes": {
      "source.ini": [
        ".buckconfig",
        ".flowconfig"
      ],
      "source.json": [
        ".arcconfig",
        "BUCK.autodeps"
      ],
      "source.python": [
        "BUCK"
      ]
    },
    "disabledPackages": [
      "spell-check",
      "language-csharp",
      "language-gfm"
    ],
    "telemetryConsent": "limited",
    "themes": [
      "atom-light-ui",
      "atom-light-syntax"
    ]
  },
  "editor": {
    "fontFamily": "Mononoki",
    "fontSize": 16,
    "invisibles": {},
    "tabType": "soft"
  }
}
```

data.title: https://atom.io/ is broken
data.body:

1. Go to https://atom.io/ in Chrome Version 54.0.2840.71 m (64-bit).

**Expected behavior:** The website looks normal

**Actual behavior:** The website does not look normal

data.title: Add and improve core.*OnStart setting descriptions
data.body:
### Description of the Change

The current description of the `core.openEmptyEditorOnStart` is misleading which has caused a lot of confusion around what this option is supposed to do or not do. Many people change this setting expecting some behavior difference when they start Atom the next time only to find out that it doesn't do anything from what they can tell. This is because Atom's default behavior in the absence of other instructions is to restore the state from the last time Atom was open, completely ignoring this setting.

There is [a way to configure Atom to not restore the last state](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/11324). The configuration setting was never exposed in the config schema though so people had to dig through the code or search through Issues and PRs to discover that it was an option. This change adds the `core.restorePreviousWindowsOnStart` setting to the schema so that is no longer necessary.

### Alternate Designs

A more [comprehensive overhaul of Atom's launch story](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10517) whether in one large change or multiple small ones is something that is being looked at but won't realistically solve this confusion in the near term.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This isn't new functionality.

### Benefits

A more clear understanding of what these settings do and do not.

### Possible Drawbacks

If not adding the `core.restorePreviousWindowsOnStart` setting to the config schema was intentional, this has the obvious drawback that it is now showing up in the Settings View.

### Applicable Issues

* Applies to #10517
* Fixes #10623

data.title: i uninstalled atom. Still showing open with atom in windows context menu
I can't reinstall Atom anymore
data.body:
### Description

I launched Atom the first time and it could install well, but I had problems saving files and running Python files and tried to reinstall it. As I couldn't find the uninstall application, I used the windows program uninstall. Only the shorcut on the desktop disappeared though, while the other files created by the installation remained. So I deleted them permanently (Sorry I am a totaly beginner in anything related to these things...) and the installation didn't worked anymore the second time I launched it. The loading gif shows for one or two seconds, then disappears and I have this error message:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23275730/20031640/ed5a1126-a38b-11e6-9b25-9d5db623540b.png)

This is the content of the setup log:

[SquirrelSetup.pdf](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/573335/SquirrelSetup.pdf)

I have been downloading Atom from https://atom.io and I am using a Windows 7 32bits. My antivirus is Avast and I am an administrator on the computer. I tried to download again the application but the installation didn't worked. I also tried to install Atom on an other user account and the installation worked, but when opening the application the Atom Welcome Screen doesn't open correctly and only displays a grey window.


### Versions
My Atom version is 1.11.2.0

data.title: Error: Running without the SUID sandbox!
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Atom mysteriously stopped working with `[30501:1104/210118:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(217)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/linux_suid_sandbox_development.md for more information on developing with the sandbox on.`

I've been using atom `1.11.2` for several weeks now, but today it stopped working. I installed using the official Debian package.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `atom -f --safe`

**Expected behavior:** I expected atom to start

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashed with error message above

### Versions

```
OS      : Ubuntu 16.10
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

data.title: Failed to remove '/usr/local/bin/atom'
data.body:
### Description

I'm seeing a misleading error message when cancelling installation of the shell commands.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5474861/20025751/ecfaa84a-a2ae-11e6-9754-d0db1cb2962d.png)

This is misleading because `usr/local/bin/atom` doesn't exist.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. If you already have the shell commands installed, execute the following from the terminal before launching Atom:
    1. `rm /usr/local/bin/atom`
    1. `rm /usr/local/bin/apm`
1. Launch Atom
1. Install the shell commands using the menu (Atom > Install Shell Commands)
2. When prompted by OSX for your username and password, click "Cancel"

**Expected behavior:** For Atom to do nothing after I click "Cancel"

**Actual behavior:** Atom prompted me with this error message

### Versions

MacOS 10.12
Atom v1.11.2

data.title: Atom Crashes when saving c++ files
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [ x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

I am trying to edit c++ files on my network drive and atom just crashes when I try to save the file. I moved the folder to a local spot on my computer and it still crashes when attempting to save
### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]: Open a file(I used a c++ file)
2. [Second Step]: hit CTRL+s or save
3. [and so on...]: Program crashes on me.

**Expected behavior:** the file to actually save

**Actual behavior:** Program crashes when saving. 

### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio

Running on a lately updated Windows 10 machine.

data.title: Feature Request: Drag and drop files from the tree view into browser to open in browser (similar to how the open file tabs can be dragged in)
data.body:
### Feautre Breakdown

1. Drag file from the tree view.
2. Drop file into browser (omnibar)
3. File is opened and rendered

Presently you can drag an open file tab into the browser and it will open/render. Can we get the same functionality from the tree view?

data.title: Force focus on command palette
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

When in the Developer Tools console and the cursor is focused in the console prompt, launching the Command Palette does not change the focus. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Developer Tools
2. Put focus on console prompt
3. Use keyboard shortcut to show the Command Palette
4. Type anything

**Expected behavior:**
Focus changes to Command Palette, so commands can be typed in

**Actual behavior:**
Focus remains in console

### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.5
git 1.8.5.2
```

data.title: Race between type-specific settings and third-party packages that update settings dynamically
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?

This bug is about a bad interaction between Atom core and a third-party package, <https://github.com/jtokoph/auto-detect-indentation>. I've already filed a bug on the package, <https://github.com/jtokoph/auto-detect-indentation/issues/23>, but it occurs to me that a proper fix for this might involve changing Atom core as well, hence this report!

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

The core code which manages per-type editor settings races with third-party code that also tries to manage editor settings. This can lead to surprising / counterintuitive results.

I ran into this with the `auto-detect-indentation` package, which tries to manage the settings of `softTabs` and `tabLength`. The steps-to-repro below are with respect to that package, and you can refer to the bug I mentioned above for a description of what I'd expect to be the interaction between the core's idea of per-type settings and what the package is trying to achieve.

I _think_ the problem boils down to the fact that <https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/text-editor-registry.js#L333-L343> often (always?) ends up running _after_ third-party packages are `activate`d (or something along those lines). In addition, it may make sense to distinguish the act of calling `editor.update` as "action taken by the core" vs. other reasons. In this case, the package in question might want to behave differently in these different cases. (But please take this all with a big grain of salt, as I'm not super-familiar with the Atom codebase.)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install the package `auto-detect-indentation`.
2. Put the following in your `config.cson`:
   
   ```
   ".js.source":
    editor:
      tabLength: 8
      tabType: "hard"
   ```

3. Open up a `.js` file with blatant two-space indentation.

**Expected behavior:**

The editor is set to two-space indentation.

**Actual behavior:**

The editor is set to eight-space hard tab indentation. If you watch carefully, you can sometimes see the indentation status briefly flash "2 Spaces" before getting thwacked to "Tabs (8 wide)".

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.3.8
```

macOS 10.11.6

data.title: Fix wrong binding on atom-environment.coffee
data.body: Context: I'm trying to run atom in the browser and have strict mode enabled and it threw on this line. We need it to be a fat arrow otherwise it's adding it to the window (or undefined in strict mode).

data.title: Feature Request: Save a regex for future usage
data.body:
I recently searched a module or extension like that but no luck.
How about adding a module like that?

> 1 - Write a regexp for your requirement.
> 2- Save it for future use.
> 3- When same regexp need, use it like syntax selector.

I really don't know is it really required/wanted by community or not. But, it's a requirement imho.

data.title: Update Octicons
data.body:
This updates the Octicons to `4.4.0` (almost newest). Some of the old icons from `2.1.2` that got removed in the meantime will still be available in Atom, so no packages should have missing icons.

Before | After
--- | ---
![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 7 54 01 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19963431/b82f68f8-a1ff-11e6-8b53-be0edb9390d7.png) | ![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 7 54 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19963430/b82f17b8-a1ff-11e6-9524-76d660fead9e.png)

Here the 20 new icons that will be available:

![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 7 22 20 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19963466/e5865618-a1ff-11e6-8a15-1c7077d05745.png)

## Concerns

All icons should be fine except that the `GitHub` wordmark is much smaller. We can update the font size in places where we use that icon, like on the About page. The "Gist" icon is also quite small, but since it's a new one, it hasn't been used anywhere.

## Remaining tasks:

- [x] Add new icons to the **Style Guide** https://github.com/atom/styleguide/pull/45
- [x] Update **Flight Manual** https://github.com/atom/flight-manual.atom.io/pull/285
- [x] Update the GitHub icon on the **About** page https://github.com/atom/about/pull/43

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8314
Will be in Atom `1.13`

data.title: Uncaught Error: The element has already been freed!
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
No as it is thrown when switching projects using [this](https://github.com/danielbrodin/atom-project-manager) plugin that causes the issue, but Atom is reporting that it is an issue with Atom, so I cannot reproduce in safe mode as that plugin does not run.

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

When switching project using [this](https://github.com/danielbrodin/atom-project-manager) plugin, Atom reports this error, but states that it is a bug within Atom and not within this plugin.  Also sometimes happens when I close a file in an open project after switching using the project manager plugin.

![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 10 54 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15265711/19963348/e112df12-a1b3-11e6-9592-4edb30cd7cfa.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project within Atom
2. Using the Project Manager Plugin, switch to another project with the original one still open

**Expected behavior:**
The project to switch but no errors be thrown

**Actual behavior:**
The project does switch successfully but this error is thrown at the same time.

### Versions

macOS: 10.12.1 (16B2657)
Atom: 1.12.0-beta6
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome: 49.0.2623.75
Node: 5.10.0
apm:  1.12.5
npm:  3.10.5
node: 4.4.5
python: 2.7.10
git: 2.9.3

data.title: Can't open notepad++ ansi encoded files properly with atom
data.body:
Hey,

I know this is a complicated and never ending story but I still try to understand, why atom is not able to operate with files from other editors in non-rare encodings.

I am working on a windows machine and produce a txt file with Notepad++ encoded with it's `ansi `encoding.
When I open that file with atom - I can not find any encoding that is able to show characters like german umlauts (ä ö ü ß )with its proper encoding. Not `ISO-88591, cp1252 `is able to encode it properly.

Cross-check that behaviour by doing it vice versa shows me the same.

I often have read that you claim to say that ANSI is wide-variety of "encoding" - yes that is true. But I also read that you claim that `windows1252 `aka `cp1252 `on windows machines ensures such an ANSI encoding.

From what I can reproduce this is wrong. CP1252 is not even ANSI certified and the encoding will differ.

A file with ANSI encoding from Notepad++ will produce the following charset:
`foo.sql: text/plain; charset=us-ascii`

While a file with cp1252 from atom will produce:
`foo.sql: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1`

Whilst they seem to only differ in some characters this is a problem with database scripts or some other usage.

I would like to ask if there will ever be a timeline when atom editor is able to support proper ANSI encoding - if that will be achieved I can finally move from Notepad++ to atom editor.

data.title: Slow dependencies loading during startup
data.body:
Will attach startup profile showing that loading the w3c-validator plugin takes 829ms.

I'd expect plugin loading to be a lot faster than that, but I'm not good enough to actually track this down to what's actually so hard about loading those requirements.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install the w3c-validator package
2. (Re)start Atom
3. Launch Timecop. Notice that w3c-validator package activation time is really bad
4. Close Atom and start with `--profile-startup`
5. Look at the profile as `Tree (Top Down)` and notice that loading the files from w3c-validator takes much too long

**Expected behavior:**
Loading the w3c-validator should be snappy, at least the dependency resolution / loading which is the part Atom / Electron provides.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Loading the w3c-validator package is really slow, which the profile indicates is due to dependency resolution performance of the platform.

### Versions

```
~/s/w3c-validation (master|✔) $ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
~/s/w3c-validation (master|✔) $ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.1
~/s/w3c-validation (master|✔) $
```
This is on OS X El Capitan, 10.11.6.

My computer has a hard drive, not an SSD, but there's plenty of RAM left and I've done this several times so everything should be cached.

data.title: Keybindings with [ or ] do not work as expected on azerty layout
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?


### Description

Keybinding with `[` or `]` (and`{` or `}`) do not work as expected on azerty layout. On the azerty (french) layout, one has to use AltGr to get a `[` or `]` or `{` or `}`. But keybinding like `ctrl-]` or `ctrl-alt-]` do not work.

A relative issue is keybinding like `ctrl-/` and `ctrl-k ctrl-0` do not work with the `shift` key down like it is needed on azerty fr layout to use to get a / or a number. (**fixed in beta**)

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Try to use a keybinding with {,[,],}
2. Fails to see it work

`ctrl-alt-]` fold one level instead of unfolding
`ctrl-alt-[` does nothing
`ctrl-]` outdent (desindent) instead of indenting
 `ctrl-[` does nothing

(_this 2 ones work as expected on beta_)
`ctrl-k ctrl-number` does work but without shift key has it should (as in *qwerty* layout)
`ctrl-/` works but without shift key (as in *qwerty* aloyut)

Another issue is that the keybinding the the menu (Edit > Folding and Edit > Lines) do not match the ones listing in Settings > Keybindings
In settings:
`ctrl-alt-{` : fold all 
`ctrl-alt-}` unfold all

in menu:
`maj-ctrl-alt-]` unfold all
`maj-ctrl-alt-[`: fold all

while `maj-]` is `}` on a qwerty keyboard it is not true on azerty layout

### Versions

It happens on atom 1.11.2 and atom 1.12-0 beta6 too on ubuntu 16.10

data.title: Atom editor SQL text overlap bug
data.body:
Atom editor does not appropriately handle sql files containing lines that extend 80 characters.  Long lines appear to corrupt lines below as the width of the editor pane narrows.

I've created a short video clip illustrating the issue.  As I expand the tree navigator width, notice how two sections of code begin to overlap:  https://gfycat.com/SoftMistyAmericancrocodile

data.title: [bug][Atom 1.11.2][Linux] Atom scrolls even when not focused
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x]  Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? (hopefully)
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Atom does not seem to lose scrolling focus upon Alt+Tab to another application and then switching back to Atom.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Be in Atom and check which line you're on
2. Alt+Tab to another application
3. Scroll up a few times
4. Alt+Tab back to Atom
5. Scroll down once

**Expected behavior:**
The file view scrolls down.

**Actual behavior:**
The current file view jumps up depending on how many scrolls you did.

### Versions
Not sure, been there for quite some time but I was not sure how to reproduce it successfully.

**OS and version**
Fedora 24, Linux 4.7.9-200.fc24.x86_64 GNU/Linux, Gnome 3.20.4

data.title: Auto-update for plugins
data.body:
Allow auto updates for plugins by either selecting plugins that will be allowed to update automatically in the background or allowing all installed plugins to auto-update.

The auto-update should be performed (as is right now) in the background but some indication that plugins are now updating should be visible in the main UI (like a progress bar with name of the plugin that is being updated.

**Steps which explain the enhancement**

1. Application has auto-update plugin option set to true
2. Plugins are installed automatically as soon as new versions are discovered
3. A notification (like a status message) is displayed in the main UI to indicate upgrade process
4. User can stop auto-update that is performed at the moment if s/he don't like the update

**Current and suggested behavior**

Consider Android use case. In first few version users had to agree and take an action on every update. It was the worst update UX I've ever seen. With platform development they decided to add auto-update option for selected applications with option to enable auto-update for all apps. For years now, in Android, applications that don't need new permissions are auto-updated by default.

The same problem now has Atom. I have many plugins installed to enhance the editor and increase productivity. However, right now I'm starting my every day at work from updating plugins and then in the evening second time at home. Every day. It would be very beneficial to the users if there were an option to enable auto-update for plugins so they don't need to care about it anymore (as probably most of them don't care right now but they forced to do so).

**Why would the enhancement be useful to most users**

You may perform a user research and ask them if they care about what version of the plugin is currently installed and if they would like to have automatic update. I feel that the most may answer no for the first one and yes to second one. 
It should increase productivity by not being distracted by plugins updates. It also increase confidence that the software installed in plugins directory is always up to date.

[List some other text editors or applications where this enhancement exists]
Not sure about that. 

**Atom Version:** It's not version related
**OS and Version:** It's not OS related

data.title: "Create issue on the <package> package" button can create very large URIs.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

"Create issue on the <package> package" button can create very large URIs.  

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Generate an error in a package that generates a long issue length (converted into URI) (I got one in `vim-mode`) 
2. Click the "Create issue on the <package> package" button

**Expected behavior:** Created ticket

**Actual behavior:** 414 Request-URI Too Large

### Suggested fix

The bug reporter could check the length of the issue, and if it's too large for a URI instead present instructions for copy-pasting the ticket. Alternatively you could bump up the uri limit of github.com.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/417142/what-is-the-maximum-length-of-a-url-in-different-browsers

### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 1.4.4
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.113
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.13.0
npm  3.10.9
node 6.9.1
python 3.5.2
git 2.10.1

Linux 4.8.4-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Oct 22 18:26:57 CEST 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux

data.title: Feature Request: Support for VB.net
data.body: I know VB.net is a bit lame compared to C++ and all that, but VB.net is quite popular. I use VB.net myself, so I'd love to see it implemented as one of the supported languages by default.

data.title: Pass package info to transpilers
data.body: Extension to #13101, this adds package name, path, and metadata as a param to transpiler methods.
